|motto = |predecessor = |successor = |formation = 2010–2014 |type = [[Grassroots]] |status = |purpose = First Nations, Metis, Inuit, environmental groups, and Watershed citizens working together for the treaty rights to protection of water, land and air, and thus for all living things today and tomorrow in the Athabasca River Watershed. |headquarters = First Nations, Athabasca |location = [[Canada]] |coords = |region_served = Northern Alberta |membership = |language = |general = |leader_title = Founders |leader_name = Jesse Cardinal in collaboration with Keepers of the Water |leader_title3 = |leader_name3 = |leader_title4 = |leader_name4 = |key_people = |main_organ = |affiliations = |budget = |num_staff = |num_volunteers =
|website = {{URL|http://www.healingwalk.org}} }}
The '''Tar Sands Healing Walk''' began in 2010. It was founded by Jesse Cardinal, in collaboration with the indigenous women of Keepers of the Athabasca.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://www.healingwalk.org/blog|title = Tar Sands Healing walk|date = November 2014|accessdate = November 2014|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Eriel Tchekwie Deranger, a Dene women, is the main organizer. One of Eriel’s co-organizers for the Healing Walk is Melina Laboucan-Massimo, a Lubicon Cree environmental activist.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://thefeministwire.com/2013/06/indigenous-feminisms-walia/|title = Feminist Wire|date = 2013|accessdate = December 2014|website = Indigenous Women: Never Idle|publisher = Feminist Wire|last = Walia|first = Harsha}}</ref> Over four consecutive years the Tar Sands Healing Walk brings together hundreds of people to walk in a spiritual gathering to protect culture, environment and climate from the expansion of the tar sands. This women's initiative aims to unite the peoples of the Athabasca River and Lake Watershed to secure and protect water and watershed lands for ecological, social, cultural and community health and well being.
== Background == The walk is a demonstration to bring awareness to the impact of the tar sands development.<ref name=":0" /> "Protests, rallies, marches are all good and necessary, but we felt like people needed something more spiritual, something to strengthen a connection to the land", said organizer Jesse Cardinal (Keepers of the Athabasca). It is called the healing walk to pray for the land and the people that have been exploited by [[tar sands]]' development. It is a reaction to the alleged legislative abuses of [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous]] treaty rights.
{{quotation|Tar Sands Healing Walk: Just start where you are, start today, small steps, let’s move forward to Pray for this land that is our home — Jesse Cardinal }}
Over 500 people travelled from all over North America to participate in this healing ceremony. The walk takes place on the territories of the Cree, Dene and Métis peoples of northern Alberta, where the impacts of the tar sands on the land and its inhabitants is devastating. [[File:Athabasca Oil Sands map.png|thumb|Athabasca Oil Sands|150px|right]]
Many people gather and camp at the Indian Beach Campsite in Anzac, just outside [[Fort McMurray]] near the [[Athabasca Oil Sands]], to participate in the walk. Native elders from all over North America lead people past lakes of tailings wastewater and infrastructure of the tar sands industry along the Athabasca River covering a walking route ranging from 14 to 16 kilometers.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.idlenomore.ca/_bill_mckibben_and_naomi_klein_to_join_canada_s_tar_sands_healing_walk|title = Idle No More|date = July 2013|accessdate = December 2014|website = Idel No more|publisher = |last = Leahy|first = Stephan}}</ref> The 2014 walk was the last official walk. "This is the last healing walk in the Athabasca region because it's time to shed light on other communities impacted by tar sands," said Jesse Cardinal, coordinator of Keepers of the Athabasca. "In order to stop the destruction, the healing has to start everywhere."
== Main issues == The walk brings awareness to Canadian human rights violations and the devastating impacts of the Athabasca Oil Sands on First Nations people. The right to clean air and clean water were outlined in [[Treaty 6]] protected by the Canadian Constitution. Under [[Treaty 6]], the Beaver Lake Cree are guaranteed the right to hunt, trap and fish on their traditional lands in perpetuity. The oil sands developments threaten the indigenous peoples' traditional way of life by destroying the very habitat upon which the animals and fish depend.<ref> {{Cite book|title = The No-Nonsense Guide to Indigenous Peoples|last = Hughes|first = Lotte|publisher = New Internationalist Publications|year = 2012|isbn = |location = Ontario|pages = }}</ref> The Canadian oil sands, also known as the tar sands, is the largest industrial project on earth, yet few Canadians are aware of the rapid pace of growth and its impacts on the environment, economy, and society. Alberta tar sands produced approximately 1.9 million barrels of oil per day in 2012. If industry and government’s expansion plans are approved this number could reach 5 million barrels per day by the end of 2030. In 2013, First Nations people witnessed the oil spill in Cold Lake, which still continues to pose problems for people in the area.<ref name=":2" /> Eight experts in environmental science, policy and risk from [[Simon Fraser University]] called for a moratorium on all new tar sands development until there is a comprehensive policy-making process for more sustainable energy development for North America.
== Health of indigenous people ==
Since 2007 higher than normal incidences of rare and deadly cancers and brain tumours have been documented by the Alberta Health Department in First Nations communities that live downstream of the oil sands.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Cancer Incidence in Fort Chipewyan, Alberta 1995-2006.|last = Chen|first = Y.|publisher = Alberta Cancer Board, Division of Population Health and Information Surveillance, Alberta Health Services|year = 2009|isbn = |location = Edmonton, AB, Canada|pages = }}</ref> [[Arsenic]], cancer causing carcinogens, are created by bitumen production. Arsenic deposits are detected in water, soil, and even in the remnants of fallen snow that have been tested in the area.
Toxins are inescapable and cancer rates are skyrocketing, especially among women and children, due to the industrial chemical exposure in the water and the air.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.vancouverobserver.com/environment/healing-walk-brings-focus-albertas-oil-development-costs-photos|title = Vancouver Observer|date = July 2013|accessdate = November 22, 2014|website = Highlighting human and environmental cost of Canada's energy policy with Healing Walk through oil sands|publisher = |last = Uechi|first = Jenni}}</ref> These chemicals are now inextricable from the landscape. This health issue for indigenous people is considered a form of industrial genocide.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fXQTyHkJkW4|title = In Solidarity with the Healing Walk: Women's voices on the oilsands, pipelines, and climate change|date = 2013|accessdate = 2014|website = you tube|publisher = Nobel Women's Initiative|last = Walia|first = Harsha}}</ref>
Cancers and asthma rates for people of Northern Alberta are higher than most places in Canada and higher than non-indigenous people.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fXQTyHkJkW4|title = Solidarity with the Healing walk|date = 2014|accessdate = November 2014|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Life expectancy for indigenous people is on average five years less than non-indigenous people.
Under the current oil sands development, woodland caribou populations are expected to disappear. This poses a problem for the hunting traditions of Canada's indigenous peoples. This threatens their food security and adds to overall health issues for the people and the environment.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The No-Nonsense Guide to Indigenous Peoples.|last = Hughes|first = Lotte|publisher = New Internationalist Publications|year = 2012|isbn = |location = Ontario|pages = }} </ref>
=== Women === ''In Solidarity with the Healing Walk: Women's voices on the oil sands, pipelines, and climate change'', discusses issues on climate change and health for indigenous women and children. Very few sources discuss these issues from the perspective of women. Women's voices are silenced in politics especially in indigenous politics.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Politics of Race In Canada: Readings in Historical Perspectives Contemporary Realities, and Future Possibilities.|last = Wallis & Fleras|first = M. & A.|publisher = Oxford Press.|year = 2009|isbn = |location = Ontario|pages = Conceptualizing the Politics of Race: Taking Race Seriously.}}</ref> Their families are more impacted by rare cancers and their children are suffering higher rates of asthma than non-indigenous children who live outside the path of environmental impact.<ref name=":2" />
Organizer Eriel Tchekwie Deranger is explicit that what is happening in her community is industrial genocide, and that her community and its traditional way of life are dying along with her people. indigenous women are very impacted, not just by tar sands, but through this representation of continued [[colonization]].<ref name=":1" />
== Human rights == In a human rights report on Canada, [[Amnesty International]] suggested that the government should have respect for indigenous rights when issuing licences for mining, logging, petroleum and other resource extraction.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://tarsandssolutions.org|title = Tar Sands Solutions|date = 2014|accessdate = November 2014|website = Tar Sand Solution|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The tar sands boom is an attack on First Nations rights, by displacing indigenous populations and dismantling crucial environmental protections.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.idlenomore.ca/_bill_mckibben_and_naomi_klein_to_join_canada_s_tar_sands_healing_walk|title = Idle No More|date = July 2013|accessdate = December 2014|website = Idle No More|publisher = |last = Leahy|first = Stephan}}</ref> The Beaver Lake Cree nation has documented 20,000 treaty rights violations linked to tar sands expansion. 80% of the traditional territories of the Athabasca Chipewyan, First Nation and the Cree First Nation are rendered inaccessible for periods of the year due to oil sands development. The land that is accessible is devastated by development.
== Health of the environment ==
Climate activist [[Bill McKibben]] notes that if development in Canada's oil sands continue, it will cause irreversible damage to the planet. Despite the economic advantages that developing oil could have on Canada, McKibben suggested that it's time to develop green energy jobs.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.vancouverobserver.com/environment/healing-walk-brings-focus-albertas-oil-development-costs-photos|title = Vancouver Observer|date = 2013|accessdate = November 2014|website = Vancouver Observer|publisher = |last = Ueichi|first = Jesse}}</ref>
Oil sands underlie approximately 140,000 square kilometers of Alberta – an area about the size of Florida.<ref name="TSS">{{Cite web|url = http://tarsandssolutions.org/tar-sands/human-right|title = TSS Tar Sands Solutions|date = 2014|accessdate = November 2014|website = TSS Tar Sands Solutions|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Oil sands leases cover about 20% of the province’s land area. In 46 years of development, only 0.15% of the environment disturbed is certified as "reclaimed." There is no way to return the [[boreal forest]] to its natural state. Over 30 million birds will be lost over the next 20 years due to tar sands development.
=== Climate ===
Dangerous [[greenhouse gas]] emissions are produced by Canada's [[Tar sands|tar sand]] that impact the Global climate.<ref name="TSS" /> The exploitation of the oil sands is the primary reason Canada will fail to meet its own greenhouse gas reduction targets. Canada’s climate performance is the worst in the entire Western world. More than 600 million cubic feet of natural gas are used every day to extract oil from the tar sands. That amount of gas is enough to heat more than 3 million Canadian homes every day. The International Energy Agency reports that increasing oil production from 1.9 million barrels to 5 million a day will lead to a catastrophic increase in the global temperature. [[Carbon emissions]] from the production and processing of the oil sands have more than doubled in the last decade and are on track to double again. The Canadian government has mounted an intensive lobbying campaign to weaken clean fuel standards that the [[European Commission]] has proposed to achieve its climate change targets.
=== Air and water ===
In northern Alberta, local Aboriginal communities are forced to endure highly degraded air and water quality. Oil sands industry used approximately 170 million cubic metres of water in 2011 to extract bitumen.<ref name="TSS"/> That is the equivalent to the residential water use of 1.7 million Canadians. 95% of the water used in tar sands surface mining is so polluted it has to be stored in toxic sludge pits. That is 206,000 litres of toxic waste discharged every day.
{{quotation| "The river used to be blue. Now it’s brown. Nobody can fish or drink from it. The air is bad. This has all happened so fast," says Elsie Fabian, 63, an elder in a Native Indian community along the Athabasca River.}}
Canada is home to two of the three largest dams in the world. They are used to hold back toxic sludge from the oil sands.<ref name="TSS"/> 11 million litres of toxic wastewater seep out of the tailing pits into the boreal forest and Athabasca river every day.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cbc.ca/player/Shows/Shows/The+Nature+of+Things/ID/2341297455/|title = Tipping Point: The Age of The Oil Sands|date = March 2013|accessdate = November 2014|website = CBC: The Nature of Things|publisher = CBC|last = Suzuki|first = David}}</ref> That is 4 billion litres a year. Air pollutant guidelines in Alberta are less stringent than international standards. Despite that, air quality objectives were exceeded 1,556 times in 2009, up from 47 times in 2004.
[[David Schindler]], environmental scientist, conducted research to assess the way water pollution was investigated in the oil sands.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cbc.ca/player/Shows/Shows/The+Nature+of+Things/ID/2341297455/|title = Tipping Point: The Age Of The Oil Sands|date = March 2013|accessdate = November 2013|website = CBC The Nature Of Things|publisher = CBC|last = Suzuki|first = David}}</ref> His research indicated that water monitoring was only regulated by the industry, not outside environmental consultants. This led to inaccurate levels of carcinogens reported over time. Chief Allan Adams of the Athabasca area is consulting with Schindler to provide evidence of water pollution linked to the seepage from the tailings ponds.
=== Land and species ===
Eighty per cent of the traditional territory of the Mikisew Cree and Athabasca Chipewyan First Nations has been rendered inaccessible for most of the year by tar sands development, which is a direct treaty rights violations. This directly impacts fishing and hunting access.
{{quotation| If we don’t have land and we don’t have anywhere to carry out our traditional lifestyles, we lose who we are as a people. So, if there’s no land, then it’s equivalent in our estimation to [[genocide]] of a people," says George Poitras of the Mikisew Cree First Nation.}}
Hunting is a traditional way of life for Canada's indigenous people.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://tarsandssolutions.org/tar-sands/human-rights|title = TSS Tar Sands Solutions|date = 2014|accessdate = November 2014|website = TSS Tar Sands Solutions|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> The loss of habitat has prevented hunting on their own land. The pollutants from the production of the oil sands iskilling animals and fish that First Nations communities relied on at one time for food. In 2007, it was suggested that wildlife has been negatively affected by the oil sands; for instance, moose were found in a 2006 study to have as high as 453 times the acceptable levels of [[arsenic]] in their systems, though later studies lowered this to 17 to 33 times the acceptable level (although below international thresholds for consumption).<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/story/2007/04/03/game-alberta.html?ref=rss | work=CBC News | title=Mixed reports on safety of eating northern Alberta game | date=3 April 2007}}</ref>
== News == * May 2013. ''[[Vancouver Observer]]'' prints academics' letter to Joe Oliver warns against promoting oil sands development. * July, 2013. ''Vancouver Observer'' reports that the walk highlights human and environmental cost of Canada's energy policy with Healing Walk through oil sands. The topic was trending nationally on Twitter and was covered by the U.K.-based ''Guardian'' as well as Al-Jazeera and ''The Wall Street Journal''. * ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' - Any new pipeline would facilitate tar sands expansion.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://canadians.org/content/tar-sands-stopping-destruction-and-starting-healing|title = Tar Sands Stop destruction and start healing|date = 2014|accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> This means more cancer causing toxins in the Athabasca River watershed and more carbon emissions coming from the Boreal Forest (which would naturally produce carbon pollution). This is the reason for fights against pipeline proposals such as the [[Keystone Pipeline|Keystone XL]] pipeline, Enbridge’s Line 9, TransCanada’s Energy East, and the B.C. pipelines — Kinder Morgan’s Trans Mountain pipeline and the Enbridge Northern Gateway — even exist is because government and industry want to expand the tar sands. They want to profit off of this dirty oil, and they don’t want anyone to get in their way.
== Testimonials == "It was unlike anything Lori Nicotine had ever seen. On the Poundmaker First Nation, words like mining, tailings and steam-assisted gravity drilling are non-existent. But on Saturday, Nicotine left the North Battleford reserve for the fifth and final Healing Walk, a 16-kilometre spiritual walk around a former tailings pond. Aboriginal chiefs and elders lead [sic] the procession, stopping intermittently to pray for the land's healing with song and tobacco offerings. As a crowd of 700 walked up Highway 63 and approached Syncrude's main plant, Nicotine looked out towards the upgraders and work trucks, and wept." (2014) <ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.healingwalk.org/stories.html|title = Tar Sands Healing Walk|date = 2014|accessdate = November 2014|website = Tar Sands Healing Walk|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>

page.title: Timeline of the American Old West

revision.text:
[[File:Western United States 1882.png|thumb|1882 hand-colored map depicting the western half of the United States]] This '''timeline of the American Old West''' is a chronology ordered list of events significant to the development of the [[American frontier|American West]] as a region of the [[United States]] prior to 1912. The term "American Old West" refers to a vast geographical area and lengthy time period of imprecise boundaries, and historians' definitions vary. The events in this timeline occurred primarily in the portion of the modern United States west of the [[Mississippi River]], and mostly in the period between the [[Louisiana Purchase]] in 1803 and the admission of the last states into the Union in 1912. A small section summarizing early exploration and settlement prior to 1803 is included to provide a foundation for later developments. Rarely, events significant to the history of the West but which occurred within the modern boundaries of Canada and Mexico are included as well. Western North America was inhabited for millennia by various groups of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]], and later served as a [[frontier]] to European powers, beginning with [[Spain|Spanish]] colonization in the 16th century. [[United Kingdom|British]], [[France|French]], and [[Russia]]n claims followed in the 18th and 19th centuries. After the [[American Revolution]], the newly independent United States began securing its own frontier from the [[Appalachian Mountains]] westward for settlement and economic investment by American citizens. The long [[territorial evolution of the United States|history of American expansion]] into these lands has played a central role in shaping American culture, iconography, and the modern national identity, and remains a popular topic for study by scholars and historians. Events listed below are notable developments for the region as a whole, not just for a particular state or smaller subdivision of the region; as historians Hine and Faragher put it, they "tell the story of the creation and defense of communities, the use of the lands, the development of markets, and the formation of states.... It is a tale of conquest, but also one of survival, persistence, and the merging of peoples and cultures."{{cite book|last1=Hine|first1=Robert V.|last2=Faragher|first2=John Mack|title=The American West : a new interpretive history|date=2000|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Conn.|isbn=0300078358|page=10.}} ==Early exploration and settlement== [[File:Coronado-Remington.jpg|thumb|''Coronado Sets Out to the North'' by American artist [[Frederic Remington]]]] [[File:The Capitol - Po' Pay.jpg|thumb|Statue of [[Popé]], or ''Po'Pay'', leader of the [[Pueblo Revolt]] in 1680, as it stands in the [[National Statuary Hall]] in the U.S. [[United States Capitol|Capitol Building]]]] [[File:Primitive plow.jpg|thumb|Natives utilize a primitive plow to prepare a field for planting near [[Mission San Diego de Alcalá]]. Drawing by A.B. Dodge, 1920.]] For almost three centuries after Columbus' voyages to the New World, much of western North America remained unsettled by European colonists, despite various territorial claims made by imperialist nations. Europeans interest in the vast territory was motivated by the search for precious metals, especially gold, and the fur trade, with miners, trappers, and hunters among the first people of European descent to permanently settle in the West.{{rp|150}} The early years were also a period of scientific exploration and survey, such that by 1830 the rough outline of the western half of the continent had been mapped to the [[Pacific Ocean]].Robert M. Utley, ed. (2003) ''The Story of The West'' DK Publishing, New York {{ISBN|0-7894-9660-7}}.{{rp|162}} {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=1|1540||Feb 23||[[Kingdom of Spain|Spanish]] [[conquistador]] [[Francisco Vázquez de Coronado]] embarks on an expedition into the unexplored territory north of [[Viceroyalty of New Spain|colonized Mexico]] to search for the fabled [[Seven Cities of Gold]]. The voyage lasts more than two years, during which Coronado travels through much of the [[Southwestern United States|American Southwest]] and as far north as present-day [[Kansas]]. His party is the first to document the geography and [[Native Americans in the United States|indigenous peoples]] of significant portions of the West.Winship, George Parker, translator and editor. ''The Journey of Coronado 1540–1542''. Golden, CO: Fulcrum Publishing, 1990. Introduction by Donald C. Cutter. {{ISBN|1-55591-066-1}} |- |rowspan=1|1579||Jun 17||[[Kingdom of England|English]] explorer [[Francis Drake]] lands his expedition on the Pacific coast of North America in present-day [[Drakes Bay]], [[California]], claiming all of the land not already under Spanish control for England.{{cite web|url=http://www.drakenavigatorsguild.org/press.html |title=Drake Navigator's Guild |publisher=Drakenavigatorsguild.org |date=17 October 2012 |accessdate=25 October 2012}} |- |rowspan=1|1598||Apr||Spanish explorer [[Juan de Oñate]] establishes [[Santa Fe de Nuevo México|Nuevo México]] in the region around the upper [[Rio Grande]] as the northernmost province of [[New Spain]], serving as its first [[List of Spanish governors of New Mexico|colonial governor]].{{cite book|last1=Weber|first1=David J.|title=The Spanish frontier in North America|date=1992|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven|isbn=0300059175|page=77|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KOPdX2qaVrkC&lpg=PA83&pg=PA77#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=27 October 2015}} |- |rowspan=1|1607|| ||[[New Spain|Spanish colonists]] establish the city of [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]] in the province of [[Santa Fe de Nuevo México]].{{cite web|url=http://www.santafenm.gov/index.asp?NID=601|title=Santa Fe – A Rich History|accessdate=October 12, 2008|publisher=City of Santa Fe|archive-url=https://archive.is/20121214025742/http://www.santafenm.gov/index.asp?NID=601|archive-date=2012-12-14|dead-url=yes|df=}} |- |rowspan=1|1610|| ||The [[Palace of the Governors]] is built in Santa Fe, the new capital of [[Santa Fe de Nuevo México|Nuevo México]]. Today it is the oldest continuously occupied public building in the United States.{{cite web|title=New Mexico's Palace of the Governors|publisher=C-SPAN|date=January 7, 2013|url=http://www.c-span.org/video/?310647-1/new-mexicos-palace-govenors|accessdate=18 Apr 2015}} |- |rowspan=1|1680||Aug 10||An alliance of [[Puebloan peoples]] coordinated by [[Popé]] initiates [[Pueblo Revolt|a mass revolt]] against Spanish colonists occupying what is now northern [[New Mexico]] in an effort to abolish European influence in the area. More than 400 people are killed and the Spanish are unable to reconquer Santa Fe for another 12 years.{{cite book|last1=Weber|first1=David J.|editor1-last=Milner|editor1-first=Clyde A., II|editor2-last=O'Connor|editor2-first=Carol A.|editor3-last=Sandweiss|editor3-first=Martha A.|title=The Oxford history of the American West|date=1994|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|pages=55–56|chapter=The Spanish–Mexican Rim}} |- |rowspan=1|1692|| ||Santa Fe is formally repossessed by the Spanish after [[Diego de Vargas]] negotiates a peace with the [[Puebloan peoples|Pueblo]] Indians. The following six years witness a difficult reinstatement of Spanish and Franciscan rule over the Pueblos, including another revolt in 1696, which is successfully countered by De Vargas and his forces.{{cite book|last1=Hine|first1=Robert V.|last2=Faragher|first2=John Mack|title=The American West : a new interpretive history|date=2000|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Conn.|isbn=0300078358|page=37.}}{{cite book|last1=Weber|first1=David J.|title=The Spanish frontier in North America|date=1992|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Conn.|isbn=0300059175|pages=137–141|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KOPdX2qaVrkC&lpg=PA245&pg=PA246#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=28 October 2015}} |- |rowspan=1|1718||May 1||The [[Presidio San Antonio de Bexar]], eventually the city of [[San Antonio, Texas|San Antonio]], is founded in [[Spanish Texas]] to undermine French claims in the area.{{cite news | author=[[Adina Emilia De Zavala]]| date=December 8, 1917| url=https://archive.org/details/historylegendsof00dezarich|title=History and legends of The Alamo and others missions in and around San Antonio| publisher=History legends of de Zarichs Online| accessdate= June 2, 2014|page=8}} |- |rowspan=1|1743||Mar 30||[[François de La Vérendrye|François]] and [[Louis-Joseph Gaultier de La Vérendrye]], on expedition west from [[Quebec]], bury an inscribed lead plate near present-day [[Fort Pierre, South Dakota]], claiming the area for [[Kingdom of France|France]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/pierre_fortpierre/verendrye_site_pierre.html|website=[[National Park Service]]|title=Vérendrye Museum|accessdate=March 12, 2015}} |- |rowspan=1|1759||Oct 7||A Spanish [[Battle of the Twin Villages|attack on a fortified Indian village]] along the [[Red River of the South|Red River]] in what is now [[Texas]] is repulsed and defeated by allied [[Wichita people|Wichita]], [[Comanche]], and [[Tonkawa]] tribes.Allen, Henry Easton. "The Parrilla Expedition to the Red River in 1759". ''The Southwestern Historical Quarterly'', Vol. 43, No. 1 (July 1939), p. 65. |- |rowspan=1|1762||Nov 13||[[Louis XV of France|France]] transfers all of [[Louisiana (New France)|its territory]] west of the [[Appalachian Mountains]] to [[Charles III of Spain|Spain]] in [[Treaty of Fontainebleau (1762)|a secret treaty]] just months prior to the negotiations that end the [[Seven Years' War|French and Indian War]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wdl.org/en/item/4397/|title=The Present State of the West-Indies: Containing an Accurate Description of What Parts Are Possessed by the Several Powers in Europe|website=[[World Digital Library]]|year=1778|accessdate=2013-08-30}} |- |rowspan=1|1769||Jul 16||Spanish [[Franciscan]]s, led by friar [[Junípero Serra]], establish [[Mission San Diego de Alcalá]] in [[The Californias|Las Californias]]. By 1823, the missionaries successfully plant a [[Spanish missions in California|series of 20 more missions]] along the coast of what becomes the Spanish province of [[Alta California]]. These missions bring European culture to the [[indigenous peoples of California]], but also enable a serious decline of from one-third to one-half of the indigenous population there during the Mission period.{{cite book|last1=Weber|first1=David J.|title=The Spanish frontier in North America|date=1992|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven, Conn.|isbn=0300059175|page=246|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KOPdX2qaVrkC&lpg=PA245&pg=PA246#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=27 October 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Nugent|first1=Walter|title=Into the West : the story of its people|date=1999|publisher=Alfred A. Knopf|location=New York|isbn=0679454799|pages=33–35|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0AvI-biS6EsC&lpg=PP1&dq=Into%20the%20West%20Google%20books&pg=PA33#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=27 October 2015}} |- |rowspan=1|1775||Aug 20||A company of Spanish soldiers establishes a site for the [[Presidio San Agustín del Tucsón]] in what is now [[Tucson, Arizona]]. |- |rowspan=1|1776||Jul 29||Two Franciscan priests lead the [[Dominguez-Escalante expedition|Domínguez–Escalante expedition]] west from Santa Fe in an attempt to find an overland route to the Spanish Catholic mission in [[Monterey, California|Monterey]]. Though they fail to reach [[Las Californias]], they explore previously unknown areas of the [[Colorado Plateau]], become the first Europeans to enter the [[Great Basin]], and establish the eastern section of what will later become the [[Old Spanish Trail (trade route)|Old Spanish Trail]].{{cite web |title=Dominguez and Escalante Expedition, 1776 |url=http://www.uintahbasintah.org/jdandemain.htm |publisher=UintahBasintah.org |accessdate=June 7, 2017}} cites: {{Citation |last1=Chavez |first1=A |last2=Waner |first2=T |year=1995 |title=The Dominguez and Escalante Journal|publisher=University of Utah Press |location=Salt Lake City}} |- |rowspan=1|1779||Sep 3||[[Comanche people|Comanche]] Indian leader [[Cuerno Verde]] is killed in combat with Spanish forces led by [[Juan Bautista de Anza]] in what is now [[Pueblo County, Colorado]].{{cite book|last=Martinez|year=2004|title=Anza and Cuerno Verde|pages=23, 52}} |- |rowspan=1|1783||Sep 3||The [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|Treaty of Paris]] is signed by the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]] and the [[United States of America]], ending the [[American Revolutionary War]]. |- |rowspan=1|1792||May 19||Captain [[George Vancouver]]'s [[Vancouver Expedition|expedition]] drops anchor near present-day [[Seattle]] and proceeds to name [[Puget Sound]], [[Mount Rainier]], [[Vashon Island]], and Restoration Point. Vancouver and his expedition are the first Europeans to explore the area, claiming it for the [[United Kingdom|British]] along with much of the [[Pacific Northwest]] coast, including [[Vancouver Island]] and the [[Columbia River]].{{cite web|last1=Rochester|first1=Junius|title=Vancouver, George (1758–1798)|url=http://www.historylink.org/index.cfm?DisplayPage=output.cfm&File_Id=5359|website=HistoryLink.org|accessdate=5 November 2015|date=4 March 2003}}{{cite book|last1=Schwantes|first1=Carlos Arnaldo|title=The Pacific Northwest : an interpretive history|date=1996|publisher=Univ. of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln|isbn=0803242255|pages=49–50|edition=Rev. and enl.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JImlIbueaXcC&lpg=PA160&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=5 November 2015}} |} {{clear}} ==1800s== [[File:Frank bond 1912 louisiana and the louisiana purchase.jpg|right|thumb|"Louisiana" and the Louisiana Purchase
Government Printing Office, 1912 Map No. 4]] [[File:Lewis and Clark.jpg|thumb|[[Meriwether Lewis]] and [[William Clark (explorer)|William Clark]]]] {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=1|1800||Oct 1||Under pressure from [[Napoléon Bonaparte]], the [[Charles IV of Spain|Kingdom of Spain]] transfers the colony of [[Louisiana (New Spain)|Louisiana]] back to the [[French First Republic|French Republic]] with the secret [[Third Treaty of San Ildefonso]]. |- |rowspan=2|1803||Apr 1||The United States [[Louisiana Purchase|agrees to buy]] the colony of [[Louisiana (New France)|La Louisiane]] from the [[French First Republic|French Republic]] for the price of [[USD|$]]15 million. |- |Dec 20||The United States officially takes control of [[Louisiana (New France)|Louisiana]], an enormous area of imprecise boundaries extending from the [[Mississippi River]] west to the [[Rocky Mountains]], more than doubling the land area of the new nation. |- |rowspan=1|1804||May 14||The [[Lewis and Clark expedition]] sets out to explore and chart the territory acquired in the [[Louisiana Purchase]]. Officially titled the Corps of Discovery, the party canoes up the [[Missouri River]] from [[St. Charles, Missouri|Saint Charles]], spending the winter at [[Fort Mandan]] on Indian territory in what is now [[North Dakota]].{{Cite web|year=1998|url=http://www.lewis-clark.org/content/content-article.asp?ArticleID=3018|title=The Lewis & Clark Expedition: A Western Adventure – A National Epic|accessdate=Sep 24, 2008}} |- |rowspan=1|1805||Nov 7||[[Lewis and Clark expedition|Lewis and Clark]] sight the Pacific Ocean for the first time, near the mouth of the [[Columbia River]]. The expedition winters at [[Fort Clatsop]] on the south side of the river, near present-day [[Astoria, Oregon]]. |- |rowspan=2|1806||Jul 15||A [[Pike expedition|U.S. Army reconnaissance expedition]] under the command of Lieutenant [[Zebulon Pike]] departs [[Fort Bellefontaine]] near [[St. Louis, Missouri|Saint Louis]] to explore the southern [[Louisiana Territory]]. |- |Sep 23||[[Lewis and Clark expedition|Lewis and Clark]] return to Saint Louis after a journey of nearly 6,000 total miles; in the past two and a half years, the party has made contact with over 70 Indian tribes and produced 140 maps, as well as documented more than 200 [[List of species described by the Lewis and Clark Expedition|new plant and animal species]].{{cite book |last='''Uldrich''' |first=Jack |title=Into the unknown: leadership lessons from Lewis & Clark's daring westward adventure |ref=Uldrich |year=2004 |publisher=AMACOM Div American Mgmt Assn. |pages=245 |isbn=0-8144-0816-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RRuKF35bPJ0C}} |- |rowspan=1|1807||Feb 26||[[Viceroyalty of New Spain|Spanish]] cavalrymen arrest the [[Pike expedition]] in the province of [[Santa Fe de Nuevo México]] (now southern [[Colorado]]). |- |rowspan=2|1808||Apr 6||German immigrant [[John Jacob Astor]] incorporates his [[American Fur Company]].{{cite book|last1=Emmerich|first1=Alexander|title=John Jacob Astor and the First Great American Fortune|date=2013|publisher=McFarland & Company, Inc., Publishers|location=Jefferson, North Carolina|isbn=978-0-7864-7213-0}} |- |Nov 10||The [[Treaty of Fort Clark]] is signed, in which the [[Osage Nation]] cedes all of its territory east of [[Fort Osage|Fort Clark]] and north of the [[Arkansas River]] to the United States.{{cite web|author1=Kappler, Charles J. (ed.)|title=TREATY WITH THE OSAGE, 1808.|url=http://digital.library.okstate.edu/Kappler/Vol2/treaties/osa0095.htm#mn6|website=Indian Affairs: Laws and Treaties - Volume II (Treaties, 1778-1883)|publisher=Oklahoma State University Library|accessdate=4 September 2017|date=1904}} |} {{clear}} ==1810s== [[File:Vue de l’etablissement russe de la Bodega, à la Côte de la Nouvelle Albion, en 1828.jpg|thumb|A view of [[Fort Ross]] in 1828 by A.B. Duhaut-Cilly]] [[File:Stephen Harriman Long portrait montage.jpg|thumb|[[Stephen Harriman Long]]]] {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=1|1810||Sep 16||Mexican priest [[Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla]] [[Grito de Dolores|proclaims]] the independence of [[Mexico]] from the [[Joseph-Napoléon Bonaparte|Kingdom of Spain]]. |- |rowspan=2|1811||May||[[Fort Astoria]] is established by [[John Jacob Astor]]'s [[Pacific Fur Company]] at the mouth of the [[Columbia River]]. It is the first American settlement on the Pacific coast. |- |Jun 15–16||Most of the crew of the ''[[Tonquin (1807)|Tonquin]]'', one of Astor's ships trading on [[Vancouver Island]], is [[Battle of Woody Point|massacred]] by [[Tla-o-qui-aht First Nations|Tla-o-qui-aht]] Indians after the captain insults a chief. The ship is [[scuttling|scuttled]] the following day in a [[magazine (artillery)|magazine]] explosion that kills at least 100 natives.Franchère, Gabriel (1851). "Narrative of a voyage to the Northwest coast of America, in the years 1811, 1812, 1813, and 1814, or, The first American settlement on the Pacific". Early Canadiana Online. http://www.canadiana.org/ECO/mtq?id=526827c58b&doc=35175. Retrieved 2017-09-05. |- |rowspan=4|1812||Mar||[[Fort Ross]] is established by [[Russian Empire|Russian]] traders on the [[California]] coast as the hub of the southernmost colony in [[Russian America]].{{cite book |title=History of Alaska: 1730–1885 |author1=Hubert Howe Bancroft |author2=Alfred Bates |author3=Ivan Petroff |author4=William Nemos |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HQQTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA482&lpg=PA482&dq=kuskof+bodega&source=bl&ots=32JOEFWJ3B&sig=E8NTuHcP2MqQGkbmgZ_DWQraFBM&hl=en&ei=KnRJS9LHMIbwsgPlt9n1Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CBIQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=rumiantzof&f=false |page=482 |year=1887 |publisher=A. L. Bancroft & company |location=San Francisco, California |accessdate=Jan 10, 2010}} |- |Apr 30||[[Louisiana]] is admitted as the [[List of U.S. states by date of admission to the Union|18th U.S. state]], and the first to include land west of the Mississippi River. It is also the first state organized from the [[Louisiana Territory|Louisiana Purchase territory]], the rest of which is soon renamed the [[Missouri Territory]]. |- |Sep 4||Scottish and Irish settlers led by [[Miles Macdonell]] formally take possession of the [[Red River Colony]]. They construct Fort Daer near present-day [[Pembina, North Dakota]], which becomes the first permanent European-American settlement in the Dakotas.{{cite journal|last1=Henderson|first1=Anne Matheson|title=The Lord Selkirk Settlement at Red River, Part 1|journal=Manitoba Pageant|date=Autumn 1967|volume=13|issue=1|url=http://www.mhs.mb.ca/docs/pageant/13/selkirksettlement1.shtml|accessdate=21 April 2018|publisher=Manitoba Historical Society}} |- |Oct 21||Carrying word of the fate of the ''Tonquin'' to [[St. Louis, Missouri|Saint Louis]], seven men of the Pacific Fur Company, led by [[Robert Stuart (explorer)|Robert Stuart]], become the first European Americans to cross the [[Continental Divide]] at [[South Pass (Wyoming)|South Pass]], in present-day [[Wyoming]]. Later in the century, the pass will be used by half a million westward migrants as part of the main route of several [[Westward Expansion Trails|emigrant trails]].Robert Stuart, Kenneth A. Spaulding (Ed.), ''On The Oregon Trail: Robert Stuart’s Journey of Discovery''. University of Oklahoma Press (1953). |- |rowspan=1|1813||Mar 29||During the [[Mexican War of Independence]], a [[Gutiérrez–Magee Expedition|joint expedition]] of Mexican and American [[filibuster (military)|filibusters]] penetrates deep into [[Spanish Texas]] and defeats a Royalist army outside [[San Antonio de Béxar]] at the [[Battle of Rosillo Creek]]. Provincial governor [[Manuel María de Salcedo]] is executed five days later.Walker, Henry P. (1962–1963) ''William McLane's narrative of the Magee-Gutierrez expedition, 1812-1813''. Austin, TX: Texas State Historical Association. {{OCLC|30688594}}. |- |rowspan=1|1817||Dec 25||Construction begins on a frontier military post known as [[Fort Smith, Arkansas|Fort Smith]] in what is now [[Arkansas]].{{cite web|title=Chronology of Fort Smith|url=http://www.fortsmithhistory.org/archive/chronology.html|website=Fort Smith Historical Society Inc.|accessdate=24 September 2017}} |- |rowspan=1|1818||Oct 20||The [[Treaty of 1818]] establishes the [[49th parallel north|49th parallel]] from [[Lake of the Woods]] west to the Rocky Mountains as the boundary between the United States and [[British North America]].{{cite web|last=LexUM |year=2000 |url=http://www.lexum.umontreal.ca/ca_us/en/cus.1818.15.en.html |title=Convention of Commerce between His Majesty and the United States of America.--Signed at London, 20th October, 1818 |work=Canado-American Treaties |publisher=University of Montreal |accessdate=2006-03-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050106120753/http://www.lexum.umontreal.ca/ca_us/en/cus.1818.15.en.html |archivedate=January 6, 2005 }} |- |rowspan=2|1819||Mar 2||The [[Arkansas Territory]] is organized. |- ||Sep 17||Intending to build forts along the [[Missouri River]], [[Yellowstone expedition|a U.S. Army expedition]] led by Colonel [[Henry Atkinson (soldier)|Henry Atkinson]] and Major [[Stephen Harriman Long]] arrives by [[paddle steamer]] at [[Fort Calhoun, Nebraska|Council Bluff]] on the river's west bank, in present-day [[Nebraska]]. It establishes what later becomes [[Fort Atkinson (Nebraska)|Fort Atkinson]], the first Army outpost in the region, but the expedition stalls there over the winter and collapses entirely in the spring.{{cite book|last=Chittenden|first=Hiram Martin|year=1902|title=The American Fur Trade of the Far West: A History of the Pioneer Trading Posts and Early Fur Companies of the Missouri Valley and the Rocky Mountains and of the Overland Commerce with Santa Fe (Vol. II)|chapter=Chapter II: The Yellowstone Expedition of 1819-1820|pages=562–587|publisher=Francis P. Harper|location=New York|doi=10.14288/1.0226338}} |} {{clear}} ==1820s== [[File:Prairie dog titian ramsay peale.jpg|thumb|''Prairie dog'' by [[Titian Ramsay Peale]], c. 1819–1821]] [[File:James Beckwourth.jpg|thumb|[[Jim Beckwourth]]]] {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=2|1820||Mar 5||Congress passes the [[Missouri Compromise]], prohibiting slavery in the unorganized territory north of [[parallel 36°30′ north|36.5° latitude]] and west of the [[Mississippi River]], except within the boundaries of the proposed state of [[Missouri]], while permitting the admission of [[Maine]] as a [[slave and free states|free state]]. Largely devised by [[Henry Clay]], it is a landmark agreement in the debate over slavery in the West. |- |May||Major [[Stephen H. Long]] leads a scientific expedition up the [[Platte River]], along the [[Front Range]] of the Rocky Mountains, south to the [[Arkansas River|Arkansas]] and [[Canadian River|Canadian]] rivers, and finally east to present-day [[Fort Smith, Arkansas]]. Among the first expeditions to bring American artists and scientists into the West, the party includes painter Samuel Seymour, artist-naturalist [[Titian Peale]], and physician [[Edwin James (scientist)|Edwin James]], who leads the first recorded ascent of [[Pikes Peak]]. Long's report, published in 1823, promotes the idea of the [[Great Plains]] as the "[[Great American Desert]]".{{cite book|last1=Rhonda|first1=James P.|editor1-last=Deverell|editor1-first=William|editor1-link=William Deverell (historian)|title=A Companion to the American West|date=2004|publisher=Blackwell Publishing|location=Malden, MA|isbn=0-631-21357-0|pages=65–68|chapter=Passion and Imagination in the Exploration of the American West}}{{cite web|title=Scientific Expedition of Major Stephen H. Long|url=http://www.kansasgenealogy.com/history/scientific_expedition.htm|website=Kansas Genealogy|accessdate=6 October 2015}} |- |rowspan=4|1821||Feb 22||The [[Adams–Onís Treaty]] takes effect exactly two years after its initial signing, defining a new border between the territory of [[New Spain]] and the United States and further securing American claims to the Louisiana Purchase and the [[Oregon Country]].{{cite book|last1=Milner|first1=Clyde A., II|editor1-last=Milner|editor1-first=Clyde A., II|editor2-last=O'Connor|editor2-first=Carol A.|editor3-last=Sandweiss|editor3-first=Martha A.|title=The Oxford history of the American West|date=1994|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=0-19-511212-1|page=158|chapter=National Initiatives}} |- |Aug 10||[[Missouri]] is admitted as the 24th U.S. state. |- |Aug 24||The [[Ferdinand VII of Spain|Kingdom of Spain]] finally recognizes the independence of [[Mexico]] with the signing of the [[Treaty of Córdoba]], ending the [[Mexican War of Independence]]. |- |Sep 1||[[William Becknell]] and a party of frontier traders leave [[New Franklin, Missouri]] bound for [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]]. The Becknell route will become the [[Santa Fe Trail]]. |- |rowspan=1|1822||Mar 6||[[William Henry Ashley]] and [[Andrew Henry (fur trader)|Andrew Henry]] place an advertisement in the ''Missouri Republican'' for one hundred "enterprising young men" to join a [[North American fur trade|trapping]] expedition to the upper [[Missouri River]]. The respondents comprise "[[Rocky Mountain Fur Company|Ashley's Hundred]]", many of whom, along with those that join in the following years, earn reputations as famous explorers and [[mountain man|mountain men]]. Sam Ford and his men are ambushed by [[Apache]] warriors led by [[Cochise]] in the [[Dragoon Mountains]], near present-day [[Benson, Arizona]], at the [[First Battle of Dragoon Springs]]. |- |May 9||The [[Second Battle of Dragoon Springs]] is fought in retaliation for the deaths of the four Confederates killed at the Apache ambush four days earlier. Rebels under Capt. [[Sherod Hunter]] take back the cattle stolen by [[Cochise]] and his warriors and kill five Apaches. |- |May 20||The [[Homestead Acts|Homestead Act of 1862]] is signed into law by President [[Abraham Lincoln]]. The pair is tracked down and arrested a few days later.{{cite news | last = Simpson | first = Claudette | title = Pearl Hart: Arizona's Woman Bandit | page = 3 | work = The Courier | date = December 18, 1981 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IqwKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DE0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5361,6690918}} |- |Jun 2||[[Butch Cassidy]] and [[Butch Cassidy's Wild Bunch|his Wild Bunch]] rob an ''[[Overland Flyer]]'' passenger train near [[Wilcox, Wyoming]], resulting in a massive but ultimately futile manhunt.{{cite news|title=Alleged Train Robber Taken|date=October 23, 1899|work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1899/10/23/102083713.pdf|accessdate=2009-05-26 | format=PDF}}{{cite web| url=http://www.wyomingtalesandtrails.com/butch2.html| title=Butch Cassidy and Sundance Kid: The Monpelier, Castle Gate, Wilcox and Winnemucca Robberies| work=Wyoming Tales and Trails| accessdate=2009-05-26}} |} {{clear}} ==1900s== [[File:WilliamJBryan1902.png|thumb|[[William Jennings Bryan]]]] {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=1|1900||May 1||A [[dust explosion]] at the Winter Quarters Mine near [[Scofield, Utah]] kills at least 200 coal miners in the [[Scofield Mine disaster]], the deadliest mining accident in American history to date.{{citation |first= Allan Kent |last= Powell |contribution= Scofield Mine Disaster |url= http://www.uen.org/utah_history_encyclopedia/s/SCOFIELD_MINE_DISASTER.html |editor-last= Powell |editor-first= Allan Kent |year= 1994 |title= Utah History Encyclopedia |location= Salt Lake City, Utah |publisher= [[University of Utah Press]] |isbn= 0874804256 |oclc= 30473917 }} |- |rowspan=2|1901||Jan 10||An [[oil well]] on the [[Spindletop]] dome near [[Beaumont, Texas]] strikes crude oil, becoming the first major [[blowout (well drilling)|gusher]] in the state and triggering the [[Texas oil boom]].{{Handbook of Texas | name=Spindletop Oilfield | id=dos03 | author=Wooster, Robert; Sanders, Christine Moor | retrieved=October 18, 2009}}, Texas State Historical Association |- |Feb 20||[[Butch Cassidy]], [[Harry Longabaugh]], and [[Etta Place]] depart the United States for [[Buenos Aires, Argentina]] aboard a British steamer.Richard M. Patterson (1998). ''Butch Cassidy: A Biography''. University of Nebraska Press, p. 316. |- |rowspan=2|1903||May 23||[[Horatio Nelson Jackson]] and [[Sewall K. Crocker]] depart [[San Francisco]] in a two-cylinder [[Winton Motor Carriage Company|Winton]] motor car. They arrive in New York City on July 26, becoming the first people to cross the continent in an [[automobile]].{{cite web|title=First to Drive across the Continent|url=http://amhistory.si.edu/onthemove/exhibition/exhibition_7_2.html|website=America on the Move|publisher=National Museum of American History|accessdate=16 October 2017}} |- |Nov 20||Legendary gunman [[Tom Horn]] is hung in [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]] for the disputed killing of 14-year-old sheepherder Willie Nickell in 1901. His trial and hanging mark the waning of the power of the cattle barons in Wyoming.{{cite web|last1=Carlson|first1=Chip|title=Tom Horn: Wyoming Enigma|url=http://www.wyohistory.org/essays/tom-horn|website=WyoHistory.org|publisher=Wyoming State Historical Society|accessdate=1 June 2016}}{{cite book|last1=Davis|first1=John W.|title=The Trial of Tom Horn|date=2016|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman, Oklahoma}} |- |rowspan=2|1905||May 15||The city of [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] is founded in [[Nevada]].{{cite book|last1=Moehring|first1=Eugene P.|last2=Green|first2=Michael S.|title=Las Vegas: A Centennial History|date=2005|publisher=University of Nevada Press|location=Reno|isbn=0874176158|page=13}} |- |Dec 30||Former Idaho Governor [[Frank Steunenberg]] is wounded by a bomb in his home in [[Caldwell, Idaho]] and dies a short time later. An investigation suggests the assassination was motivated by prior [[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho labor confrontation of 1899|labor unrest]] in Idaho's mining communities.{{cite book|last=Horsley|first=Albert|title=The Confessions and Autobiography of Harry Orchard|year=1907}} |- |rowspan=1|1906||Apr 18||[[1906 San Francisco earthquake|An earthquake]] and resulting fires devastate the city of [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]] and neighboring communities, killing at least 3,000 people and leaving nearly three-fourths of the [[San Francisco Bay Area|Bay Area]]'s population homeless.[http://www.sfmuseum.net/hist10/06timeline.html Timeline of the San Francisco Earthquake April 18 – 23, 1906], The Virtual Museum of the City of San Francisco |- |rowspan=1|1907||Nov 16||[[Oklahoma]] is admitted as the 46th U.S. state. |- |rowspan=2|1908||Feb 29||[[Pat Garrett]] is murdered under mysterious circumstances near [[Las Cruces, New Mexico|Las Cruces]], [[New Mexico Territory]].Metz, Leon C. ''Pat Garrett: The Story of a Western Lawman''. pp. 285–286.Gardner, Mark Lee. ''To Hell on a Fast Horse'', p. 229 |- |Nov 7||[[Butch Cassidy]] and the [[Sundance Kid]] are reportedly found dead following a shootout with police in the town of San Vicente, [[Bolivia]].{{cite news|last1=Friedman-Rudovsky|first1=Jean|title=On the Trail of Butch Cassidy, in Bolivia|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1951085,00.html|accessdate=18 August 2017|work=TIME|date=December 31, 2009}} |} {{clear}} ==1910s== [[File:Charles Marion Russell.jpg|thumb|[[Charles Marion Russell]]]] {|class=wikitable !Year !width=55|Date !Event |- |rowspan=1|1910||Nov 20||The [[Mexican Revolution]] begins when [[Francisco I. Madero]] publishes his [[Plan of San Luis Potosi|Plan of San Luis de Potosí]], calling on the [[Mexico|Mexican]] people to revolt against the corrupt authoritarian presidency of [[Porfirio Díaz]].{{cite web|last1=Halsall|first1=Paul|title=Francisco Madero: The Plan of San Luis Potosi, November 20, 1910|url=https://sourcebooks.fordham.edu/halsall/mod/1910potosi.html|website=Modern History SourceBook|publisher=United States Congress, Senate Subcommittee on Foreign Relations, Revolutions in Mexico, 62nd Congress, 2nd Session (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1913), pp. 730-736, passim.|accessdate=20 October 2017|language=English|date=July 1998}} |- |rowspan=2|1912||Jan 6||[[New Mexico]] is admitted as the 47th U.S. state. |- |Feb 14||[[Arizona]] is admitted as the 48th U.S. state. It is the last state to be admitted in the [[contiguous United States]], marking the complete political incorporation of U.S. territorial acquisitions west of the Mississippi River.{{cite book|last1=Milner|first1=Clyde A., II|editor1-last=Milner|editor1-first=Clyde A., II|editor2-last=O'Connor|editor2-first=Carol A.|editor3-last=Sandweiss|editor3-first=Martha A.|title=The Oxford history of the American West|date=1994|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|pages=156–157|chapter=National Initiatives}} |- |rowspan=1|1916||Dec 5||The [[Jarbidge Stage Robbery|last stagecoach robbery]] in American history occurs at Jarbidge Canyon, [[Nevada]], when three robbers hold up a [[United States Post Office Department|U.S. Post Office Department]] stagecoach, shoot the driver, and steal $4,000 in cash. The criminals are captured without incident soon after. |} {{clear}} ==See also== {{portal|History|United States}} *[[Historic regions of the United States]] *[[Territorial evolution of the United States]] *[[List of Old West gunfights]] *[[Western United States]] **[[Mountain States]] **[[Northwestern United States]] **[[Southwestern United States]] **[[Pacific States]] **[[Great Plains]] **[[Rocky Mountains]] **[[Great Basin]] **[[Sierra Nevada (United States)]] **[[Cascade Range]] {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|22em}} ==External links== {{sister project links|Western United States}} * [https://www.pbs.org/weta/thewest/events/ ''New Perspectives On The West'']. 99-AUT-baa to 99-AUT-bad |guthrie=S.20 (S.21) |map=South Africa Venda speakers proportion map.svg |mapcaption=Geographical distribution of Tshivenda in South Africa: proportion of the population that speaks Tshivenda at home. {{columns |col1= {{legend|#EDF8E9|0–20%}} {{legend|#BAE4B3|20–40%}} {{legend|#74C476|40–60%}} |col2= {{legend|#31A354|60–80%}} {{legend|#006D2C|80–100%}}}} |map2=South Africa Venda speakers density map.svg |mapcaption2=Geographical distribution of Tshivenda in South Africa: density of Tshivenda home-language speakers. {{columns |col1= {{legend|#ffffcc|<1 /km²}} {{legend|#ffeda0|1–3 /km²}} {{legend|#fed976|3–10 /km²}} {{legend|#feb24c|10–30 /km²}} {{legend|#fd8d3c|30–100 /km²}} |col2= {{legend|#fc4e2a|100–300 /km²}} {{legend|#e31a1c|300–1000 /km²}} {{legend|#bc0026|1000–3000 /km²}} {{legend|#800026|>3000 /km²}}}} |notice=IPA |sign=[[Signed Venda]] |glotto=vend1245 |glottorefname=Venda }} '''Venda''' or '''Tshivenda''', also known as ''Tshivenḓa'' or ''Luvenḓa'', is a [[Bantu languages|Bantu]] language and an official language of [[South Africa]]. It is mainly spoken by the [[Venda people]] in the northern part of South Africa's [[Limpopo Province]], as well as by some [[Lemba people]] in [[Zimbabwe]]. The Venda language is related to [[Kalanga language|Kalanga]] (Western Shona, different from [[Shona language|Shona]], official language of Zimbabwe) which is spoken in Botswana and Zimbabwe. During the [[Apartheid]] era of South Africa, the [[bantustan]] of [[Venda]] was set up to cover the Venda speakers of South Africa. According to the 2011 census, Venda speakers are concentrated in the following areas: [[Makhado Local Municipality]], with 350,000 people; [[Thulamela Local Municipality]], with 370,000 people; [[Musina Local Municipality]], with 35,000 people; and [[Mutale Local Municipality]], with 89,000 people. The total number of speakers in Vhembe district currently stands at 844,000. In Gauteng province, there are 275,000 Venda speakers. Fewer or less than 10,000 people are spread across South Africa and that makes total number of Venda speakers in South Africa at 1.2 million people or just 2.2% of South Africa's population, making Venda speakers the second smallest minority language in South Africa, after the [[Southern Ndebele language|Ndebele language]], which number 1.1 million speakers. ==Writing system== The Venda language uses the [[Latin alphabet]] with five additional accented letters. There are four dental consonants with a [[circumflex accent]] below the letter (''ḓ, ḽ, ṋ, ṱ'') and an [[overdot]] for velar ''ṅ''. Five vowel letters are used to write seven vowels. The letters C, J and Q are used only for foreign words and names. {| cellpadding=4 style="font-size:larger; text-align:center;" summary="Thirty-one letters of the Venda alphabet, capital and small" |+ style="font-size:smaller;" | The Venda alphabet |- | A a || B b || (C c) || D d || Ḓ ḓ || E e || F f || G g || |- | H h || I i || (J j) || K k || L l || Ḽ ḽ || M m || N n || |- | Ṋ ṋ || Ṅ ṅ || O o || P p || (Q q) || R r || S s || T t || |- | Ṱ ṱ || U u || V v || W w || X x || Y y || Z z || |} ===Unicode=== The extra letters have the following [[Unicode]] names: * Ḓ U+1E12 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER D WITH CIRCUMFLEX BELOW * ḓ U+1E13 LATIN SMALL LETTER D WITH CIRCUMFLEX BELOW * Ḽ U+1E3C LATIN CAPITAL LETTER L WITH CIRCUMFLEX BELOW * ḽ U+1E3D LATIN SMALL LETTER L WITH CIRCUMFLEX BELOW * Ṅ U+1E44 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER N WITH DOT ABOVE * ṅ U+1E45 LATIN SMALL LETTER N WITH DOT ABOVE * Ṋ U+1E4A LATIN CAPITAL LETTER N WITH CIRCUMFLEX BELOW * ṋ U+1E4B LATIN SMALL LETTER N WITH CIRCUMFLEX BELOW * Ṱ U+1E70 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER T WITH CIRCUMFLEX BELOW * ṱ U+1E71 LATIN SMALL LETTER T WITH CIRCUMFLEX BELOW ===Luṱhofunḓeraru lwa Mibvumo=== {{Importance section|date=July 2017}} The ''sintu'' writing system ''Isibheqe Sohlamvu/[[Ditema tsa Dinoko]]'', known technically in Venda as ''Luṱhofunḓeraru lwa Mibvumo'', is also used for the Venda language.{{cn|date=July 2017}} {| class="wikitable" !''ṱala'' "divorce" | [[File:Ṱala.jpg|thumbnail|left|[t̪ʼaːɽa]]] !''tala'' "draw a line" | [[File:Tala2.jpg|thumbnail|left|[tʼaːɽa]]] |- |} ==Phonology== Venda distinguishes [[dental consonant|dental]] ''ṱ, ṱh, ḓ, ṋ, ḽ'' from [[alveolar consonant|alveolar]] ''t, th, d, n, l'' as well as (like in [[Ewe language|Ewe]]) [[labiodental]] ''f, v'' from [[bilabial]] ''fh, vh'' (the last two are slightly [[labialization|rounded]]). There are five vowel sounds: {{IPA|/i ɛ a ɔ u/}}. There are no clicks; ''x'' has the sound of ''ch'' in ''loch'' or ''Bach''. As in other South African languages like the [[Zulu language|Zulu]], ''ph, ṱh, th, kh'' are aspirated and [[ejective]]: ''p, ṱ, t, k''. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! rowspan="2" colspan="2" | ! colspan="3" | [[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ! rowspan="2" |[[Labiodental consonant|Labio-

Similar to the ''ch'' in Scottish ''loch''. |- | xw || {{IPA|[xw]}} || |- | y || {{IPA|[j]}} || |- | z || {{IPA|[z]}} || |- | zh || {{IPA|[ʒ]}} || |- | zw || {{IPA|[ʐ]}} || |} ===Tones=== Venda has a specified tone, {{sc|high}}, with unmarked syllables having a low tone. Phonetic falling tone occurs only in sequences of more than one vowel or on the penultimate syllable if the vowel is long. Tone patterns exist independently of the consonants and vowels of a word and so they are [[word tone]]s. Venda tone also follows [[Meeussen's rule]]: when a word beginning with a high tone is preceded by that high tone, the initial high tone is lost. (That is, there cannot be two adjacent marked high tones in a word, but high tone spreads allophonically to a following non-tonic ("low"-tone) syllable.) There are only a few tone patterns in Venda words (no tone, a single high tone on some syllable, two non-adjacent high tones), which behave as follows: {|class=wikitable !Word!!Pattern!!After L!!After H!!Notes |- !thamana | –.–.– |thàmà:nà||thámâ:nà |Unmarked (low) tone is raised after a high tone. That is, the preceding tone spreads. |- !dukaná | –.–.H |dùkà:ná||dúkâ:ná |A preceding high tone spreads but drops before the final high tone. |- !danána | –.H.– |dàná:nà||dánâ:nà |rowspan=2|The pitch peaks on the tonic syllable, and a preceding non-adjacent high tone merges into it. |- !phaphána | –.H.– |phàphá:ná||pháphâ:nà |- !mádzhie | H.– |má:dzhíè||mâ:dzhìè |rowspan=3|Initial high tone spreads. With an immediately preceding high tone, that initial tone is lost.
(The preceding tone also spreads but not as far.) |- !dákalo |H.–.– |dáká:lò||dákà:lò |- !khókholá | H.–.H |khókhô:lá||khókhò:lá |} == References == ==Sources== *G. USA: $20 million USD | conviction_status = Arrested | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Vicente Carrillo Fuentes''' (born October 16, 1962), commonly referred to by his alias '''El Viceroy''', is a [[Mexican people|Mexican]] suspected [[drug lord]] and former leader of the [[Juárez Cartel]], a drug trafficking organization. The cartel is based in Chihuahua, one of the primary transportation routes for billions of dollars' worth of illegal drug shipments entering the [[United States]] from Mexico annually. He was one of Mexico's [[List of Mexico's 37 most-wanted drug lords|most-wanted drug lords]].{{cite web|title=DEA FUGITIVE: CARRILLO-FUENTES, Vicente|url=http://www.justice.gov/dea/fugitives/internl/carrillo.htm|publisher=[[Drug Enforcement Administration]]|accessdate=4 October 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429095902/http://www.justice.gov/dea/fugitives/internl/carrillo.htm|archivedate=29 April 2011|deadurl=no}} ==Early life== Vicente Carrillo Fuentes was born in Guamuchilito, Navolato, Sinaloa, Mexico on 16 October 1962 to Vicente Carrillo and Aurora Fuentes. He had seven siblings: Angélica, [[Amado Carrillo Fuentes|Amado]], Cipriano, Guadalupe, Alberto, Rodolfo and José Cruz Carrillo Fuentes (Vicente being the fourth one).{{cite news|title=¿Quién es Vicente Carrillo Fuentes? |url= http://www.milenio.com/policia/Vicente_Carrillo_Fuente-cartel_de_Juarez-capturan_a_El_Viceroy-Senor_de_los_Cielos_0_387561535.html |accessdate=10 October 2014|publisher=[[Milenio]]|date=9 October 2014|language=Spanish}} All are nephews of [[Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo]], a former drug lord. == Family relations and alliances == The [[Juárez Cartel]] was founded by his brother [[Amado Carrillo Fuentes]] following the death of [[Pablo Acosta Villarreal]]. Cipriano Carrillo Fuentes died in the mid-1980s by gunshot under mysterious circumstances. Amado began in the drug business under the tutelage of his uncle and eventually formed the Juárez Cartel by 1993. Amado brought in his brothers and eventually his son [[Vicente Carrillo Leyva]], who was arrested on April 1, 2009.{{cite news|last=Castillo|first=Eduardo E.|title=Vicente Carrillo Leyva, Wanted Mexican Drug Suspect, Detained|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/04/02/vicente-carrillo-leyva-wa_n_182367.html|accessdate=4 October 2012|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=2 April 2009|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BAZZhGhP?url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/04/02/vicente-carrillo-leyva-wa_n_182367.html|archivedate=4 October 2012|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last=Ellingwood|first=Ken|title=Mexico arrests suspected No. 2 in Juarez drug cartel|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/latinamerica/la-fg-mexico-capture3-2009apr03,0,7149086.story|accessdate=4 October 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=3 April 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304072003/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/latinamerica/la-fg-mexico-capture3-2009apr03,0,7149086.story |archivedate=4 March 2011|deadurl=no|location=[[Mexico City]]}} When Amado died on July 3, 1997 following complications from plastic surgery, a brief turf war began in Juarez over the leadership of the cartel. Vicente would emerge as the victor after defeating the Muňoz Talavera brothers for control of the cartel. Vicente formed a partnership with [[Juan José Esparragoza Moreno]], his brother Rodolfo Carrillo Fuentes, his nephew Vicente Carrillo Leyva, Ricardo Garcia Urquiza and the [[Beltrán-Leyva Cartel|Beltrán Leyva brothers]]. He kept in service several lieutenants formally under his brother, such as "El Chacky" Hernandez. The organization was in flux by the time Vicente took control of the cartel and the death of Amado created a large power vacuum in the Mexican underworld. The [[Arellano Félix]] brothers became the most powerful organization during the 1990s while Vicente was able to avoid direct conflict and increase the strength of the Juárez Cartel. The relationship between the Carrillo Fuentes clan and the other members of the organization grew unstable towards the end of the 1990s and into the 2000s. In 2001 after the escape from prison by [[Joaquín Guzmán Loera]], many of the Juárez Cartel members defected to Guzmán's [[Sinaloa cartel]]. In 2004 Rodolfo Carrillo was killed outside of a movie theatre allegedly at the behest of Guzmán Loera. Vicente Carrillo responded by having Guzmán Loera's brother "El Pollo" assassinated in prison. This sparked off a turf war; however, it seemed that the war between the two was on hold during 2005 and 2006 because the [[Sinaloa Cartel]] was engaged in a vicious war with their rival, the [[Gulf Cartel]]. During this time, the leadership of the cartel was between Vicente Carrillo and Ricardo García Urquiza, who was arrested in November 2005.{{cite news|last=Marshall|first=Claire|title=Mexico arrests drug cartel head|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4458426.stm|accessdate=4 October 2012|newspaper=[[BBC News]]|date=22 November 2005|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BAZs9tTt?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/4458426.stm|archivedate=4 October 2012|deadurl=no|location=[[Mexico City]]|df=dmy-all}} The cartel had become factionalized between the groups loyal to the Carrillo family and the groups loyal to Juan José Esparragoza Moreno and Guzmán Loera's [[Sinaloa Cartel]]. The Juárez Cartel, under the control of Vicente Carrillo Fuentes and his nephew Vicente Carrillo Leyva, was placed under a large degree of pressure following the "[[House of Death]]" case, in which the organization was penetrated by law enforcement, but was corrupted by the fact that the informant participated in murders. In 2008, 200 murders occurred in the first three months and it appeared that the war between the Sinaloa Federation and the remnants of the Juárez Cartel was back on. President [[Felipe Calderón|Calderón]] sent thousands of troops to [[Ciudad Juárez]]. The Juárez Cartel, at one time the most powerful in Mexico, is a shadow of its former self. ==Charges== Carrillo Fuentes was charged in a forty-six count indictment in the Western District of [[Texas]] with continuing criminal enterprise, importation and possession with intent to distribute [[cocaine]] and [[marijuana]], conspiracy to import and possess with intent to distribute cocaine and marijuana, as well as with [[money laundering]], tampering with a witness, ordering the intentional killing of individuals to prevent communication of information by them to U.S. law enforcement, and murder in furtherance of a continuing criminal enterprise. The U.S. Departments of State offered a reward of up to $5 million [[USD]] for information leading to the arrest and/or conviction of Vicente Carrillo Fuentes.{{cite web|title=FBI – Vicente Carrillo Fuentes|url=https://www.fbi.gov/wanted/cei/vicente-carrillo-fuentes|publisher=[[Federal Bureau of Investigation]]|accessdate=4 October 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BAZ1PHlm?url=http://www.fbi.gov/wanted/cei/vicente-carrillo-fuentes|archivedate=4 October 2012|deadurl=no|location=[[El Paso, Texas]]|df=dmy-all}} ===Kingpin Act sanction=== On 1 June 2000, the [[United States Department of the Treasury]] sanctioned Carrillo Fuentes under the [[Foreign Narcotics Kingpin Designation Act]] (sometimes referred to simply as the "Kingpin Act"), for his involvement in drug trafficking along with eleven other international criminals.{{cite web|title=DESIGNATIONS PURSUANT TO THE FOREIGN NARCOTICS KINGPIN DESIGNATION ACT|url=http://www.treasury.gov/resource-center/sanctions/Programs/Documents/narco_designations_kingpin.pdf|publisher=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]|accessdate=28 May 2014|page=1|date=15 May 2014}} The act prohibited U.S. citizens and companies from doing any kind of business activity with him, and virtually froze all his assets in the U.S.{{cite web|title=An overview of the Foreign Narcotics Kingpin Designation Act|url=http://www.assetsearchblog.com/uploads/file/drugs.pdf|publisher=[[United States Department of the Treasury]]|accessdate=28 May 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528053616/http://www.assetsearchblog.com/uploads/file/drugs.pdf|archivedate=28 May 2014|page=1|date=2009}} ==Arrest== Carrillo Fuentes was arrested in a joint operation by the [[Mexican Army]] and [[Federal Police (Mexico)|Federal Police]] in [[Torreón, Coahuila]] on 9 October 2014.{{cite news|title=Capturan a ‘El Viceroy’|url=http://www.milenio.com/policia/Amado_Carrillo-Vicente_Carrillo_Fuentes-capturan_a_El_Viceroy-cartel_de_Juarez_0_387561456.html|accessdate=9 October 2014|publisher=[[Milenio]]|date=9 declaration.{{cite news|last1=Hernández|first1=Hugo|title=Sigue declarando en la SEIDO Vicente Carrillo|url=http://www.oem.com.mx/laprensa/notas/n3568292.htm|accessdate=14 October drug trafficking and organized crime offenses.{{cite news|title=Dictan formal prisión a Vicente Carrillo Fuentes|url=http://diario.mx/Nacional/2014-10-14_3887befd/dictan-formal-prision-a-vicente-carrillo-fuentes/|accessdate=15 October 2014|publisher=El Diario de Juárez|date=14 October 2014|language=Spanish}} On 14 October 2014, Carrillo Fuentes was transferred to the [[Federal Social Readaptation Center No. 2]], a federal maximum-security prison (commonly referred to as "Puente Grande"), in [[Jalisco]] state.{{cite news|last1=Martínez|first1=Jorge|title=Encarcelan a Vicente Carrillo en penal de Puente {{Infobox Korean name| hangul=예맥 |hanja={{linktext|濊|貊}} |rr=Yemaek |mr=Yemaek }} '''Yemaek''' or '''Yamaek''' ({{IPA-ko|jemɛk}}) were an ancient tribal group regarded by many scholars as being one of the several ancestors of the modern [[Koreans|Korean]] ethnic group.<ref>{{cite book |last= Pai|first= Hyung Il|date= 2000|title= Constructing "Korean" Origins: A Critical Review of Archaeology, Historiography, and Racial Myth in Korean State-formation Theories|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=QxztLeLoVkQC&dq=yemaek+korean+ancestor&source=gbs_navlinks_s|publisher= Harvard University Asia Center|page= 86|isbn=9780674002449|quote= "As the first "Koreans", the Yemaek are considered responsible for the formation of Tan'gun's kingdom of Kochoson"}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last= Xu|first= Stella Yingzi|date= 2007|title= That Glorious Ancient History of Our Nation: The Contested Re-readings of "Korea" in Early Chinese Historical Records and Their Legacy on the Formation of Korean-ness|url= http://search.proquest.com/docview/304872860|location= Ann Arbor|publisher= Proquest|page= 220|isbn=9780549440369|quote= "The majority of the Kija Choson and Wiman Choson people were Yemaek, the ancestors of the Korean people"}}</ref> These people most commonly dwelt in [[Manchuria]] and the [[Korean Peninsula]]. They had ancestral ties to various [[Korea]]n kingdoms including [[Gojoseon]], [[Buyeo Kingdom|Buyeo]], [[Goguryeo]], and tribes including [[Okjeo]], [[Dongye]], and Yangmaek (양맥; 梁貊) and Sosumaek (소수맥; 小水貊).
==Origin== Yemaek is believed to be a combination of Ye (濊·穢·薉) and Maek (貊·貉) people of two neighboring cultures.<ref>[http://www.readannals.com/forum/attachments/day_070424/20070425_0a55720a0021f13d79fasdtHv3bNuXuT.pdf 关于东北古代史研究的几个问题]</ref> The main culture is the Xitunshan culture (西团山文化). He Qiutao (何秋涛) said Ye is the short name of [[Buyeo kingdom|Buyeo]].<ref>[http://www.zzsck.com/Article/?875.html 民族探幽：夫余与秽貊]</ref> Dongye first appears in history as a vassal state of [[Gojoseon]] until its fall to China in 108 BCE.<ref>[http://enc.daum.net/dic100/viewContents.do?&m=all&articleID=b05d1565a]</ref> It was known as the '''Huiyetou''' (穢邪頭) state in [[Shuowen Jiezi]].<ref>[http://222.216.4.165:8088/periodical/periodical.articles/hljmzck/hljm2004/0401pdf/040112.pdf the Investigation about the Hui Country]</ref><ref>[http://kanji-database.sourceforge.net/dict/swjz/v22.html 說文解字第十一篇下]</ref> It later became a vassal of the increasingly powerful [[Goguryeo]]. According to the Chinese [[Records of Three Kingdoms]], Ye worshiped tigers,<ref>[[Chen Shou]],''[[Records of Three Kingdoms]]'', Volume 30, ''Weizhi'', Chapter 30, ''Dongyizhuan'', "常用十月節祭天，晝夜飲酒歌舞，名之爲舞天，又祭虎以爲神"</ref> whereas according to ''[[Erya]]'', Maek means bears. [[Gomnaru]], the capital of [[Baekje]], also means the "bear port". Historians suggest tigers and bears may have been [[totems]] worshiped by Ye and Maek tribes.
Several history books suggest [[Gojoseon]], the first Korean kingdom in history, was established by Yemaek. :*In [[Dangun]]'s ancestry legend of [[Gojoseon]] recorded in [[Samguk Yusa]], a tiger and a bear prayed to [[Hwanung]] that they may become human but had to stay in a cave eating only garlic and mugwort, and while the tiger shortly gave up and left the cave, the bear remained and after 21 days was transformed into a woman who later married Hwanung and then gave birth to [[Dangun Wanggeom]],<ref>[[Il-yeon]], ''[[Samguk Yusa]]'', Vol.1, ''Giyi Chapter I'', [http://www.history.go.kr/url.jsp?ID=NIKH.DB-sy_001r_0020_0020_0020]</ref> which is believed to symbolize combination of Ye and Maek tribes into one Yemaek tribe.<ref>[http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/society/schooling/328862.html Hankyore, 'Why are Korean more familiar with tigers than with bears?'], Dec 21, 2008</ref> :*Tombstone of Yeon Namsan (연남산) found in [[Luoyang]] says Yeon, son of [[Goguryeo]]'s leader [[Yeon Gaesomun]], is a [[Gojoseon|Joseon]] person.<ref>[http://www.history.go.kr/url.jsp?ID=NIKH.DB-gs_kr_006_0010_0040_0020]</ref> :*[[Gojoseon]] is called "Yemaek Joseon" in the Chinese [[Records of the Grand Historian]], which says Yemaek Joseon bordered on [[Xiongnu]] around 200 BC.<ref>[[Sima Qian]],''[[Records of the Grand Historian]]'', Vol.110, ''[[Xiongnu]] Liezhuan'',"諸左方王將居東方，直上穀以往者，東接穢貉朝鮮"</ref>
==Language== {{Main|Ye-Maek language|Buyeo languages}}
There have been some academic attempts to recover Yemaek words based on the fragments of [[toponyms]] recorded in the [[Samguk Sagi]] for the areas once possessed by Goguryeo and Buyeo-Baekje.
==Legacy== According to [[Samguk Sagi]], [[Silla]] was established as a confederacy of six clans composed of [[Gojoseon|Joseon]] refugees,<ref>[[Kim Bu-sik]], ''[[Samguk Sagi]]'', ''Silla Bongi'', Vol.1, "先是朝鮮遺民分居山谷之間爲六村"[http://www.history.go.kr/url.jsp?ID=NIKH.DB-sg_001r_0020_0010]</ref> and the Royal Seal of Ye (예왕지인; 濊王之印), previously used by [[Buyeo Kingdom|Buyeo]]'s kings, was found in [[Silla]] in 19 AD and presented for King [[Namhae of Silla]].<ref>[[Kim Bu-sik]], ''[[Samguk Sagi]]'', ''Silla Bongi'', Vol.1, "春二月 北溟人耕田 得濊王印獻之"[http://www.history.go.kr/url.jsp?ID=NIKH.DB-sg_001r_0030_0130]</ref>
